title: Ev-3DOD: Pushing the Temporal Boundaries of 3D Object Detection with Event Cameras
author: Hoonhee Cho (KAIST), Jae-young Kang (KAIST), Youngho Kim (KAIST), Kuk-Jin Yoon (KAIST), ...
relevance_why: The proposed work involves 3D object detection using event cameras, which may inspire techniques for audio-visual integration in sound event recognition tasks.
background: Detecting 3D objects in real-time using point cloud data from various sensors is essential for autonomous driving systems, particularly in challenging temporal conditions.
contribution: This paper introduces the Ev-3DOD methodology, integrating event cameras with traditional sensors for real-time 3D object detection during blind time, achieving improved accuracy and speed.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods face limitations with fixed frame rate sensors, causing detection gaps due to blind times where data is unavailable.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes asynchronous event cameras to capture data constantly, enabling detection even during these blind periods.

key_innovation: Combines high temporal resolution of event cameras with LiDAR and frame camera data to produce reliable 3D object detection in time-critical scenarios.
real_world_impact: Enhances the reliability of autonomous systems by improving 3D perception capabilities, which could lead to safer autonomous navigation.
limitations: The integration between event data and LiDAR might face challenges in alignment and requires precise calibration.

new_terms.event camera: **Event camera** is a type of visual sensor that captures changes in the scene as a stream of data, rather than capturing frames at fixed intervals, providing high temporal resolution and low latency.

open_sourcing: The code and dataset are available at https://github.com/mickeykang16/Ev3DOD
